titleStmt.title: Qui chetat chetabitur: or, Tyburne cheated. Being, a poeme, upon the three regicides Munson, Mildmay and Wallopp; who were drawn upon hurdles to Tyburne on the 27th. of January, 1661.

editionStmt.edition: This text is an enriched version of the TCP digital transcription B04969 of text R226720 in the English Short Title Catalog (Wing Q203). Textual changes and metadata enrichments aim at making the text more computationally tractable, easier to read, and suitable for network-based collaborative curation by amateur and professional end users from many walks of life. The text has been tokenized and linguistically annotated with MorphAdorner. The annotation includes standard spellings that support the display of a text in a standardized format that preserves archaic forms ('loveth', 'seekest'). Textual changes aim at restoring the text the author or stationer meant to publish.

respStmt.resp: This text has not been fully proofread

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 7 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 1 1-bit group-IV TIFF page image.

titleStmt.title: Qui chetat chetabitur: or, Tyburne cheated. Being, a poeme, upon the three regicides Munson, Mildmay and Wallopp; who were drawn upon hurdles to Tyburne on the 27th. of January, 1661.

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed by Edward Crowch [sic] dwelling on Snowhill,
publicationStmt.date: 1661. [i.e. 1662] Who these traitors would once have hang'd.

notesStmt.note: Date of publication from Wing CD-ROM, 1996.
Verse: "Great, and grave Tyburne, wee are sent".
Reproduction of original in the British Library.

keywords.term: Great Britain -- History -- Charles I, 1625-1649 -- Poetry -- Early works to 1800.
